prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2310_OI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [O I] 145 micron fine structure line and dust continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We request to observe the [O I] 145 micron line emission from J2310+1855. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line at 0.6" resolution suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of ~3.2 kpc (deconvolved source size of FWHM~0.6"). Here we request to observe the [O I] line at ~0.5" resolution, i.e. in C34-3 configuration. The resolution is comparable to the observations of other fine structure and CO lines we propose here, and is sufficient to accurately determine the total flux and measure/tightly constrain the source size of the [O I] line emission. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] detection is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [O I] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: The FIR luminosity estimated with previous submillimeter and millimeter observations and a modified-blackbody model (T_dust of 47 K and emissivity index of 1.6, typical for high-z millimeter bright quasars, Beelen et al. 2006) is about 2.4x10^13 Lsun. Adopting the typical [OI]/FIR luminosity ratio range of 1x10^-5 to 8x10^-5 for AGN-starburst systems (Gracia-Carpio et al. 2011), we estimate the [O I] line flux to be 0.2 to 1.8 Jy km/s with peak line flux density of 0.6 to 4.5 mJy. The [C II] FWHM line width of 400 km/s is used in the calculation. The dust continuum flux density at the [O I] frequency is 10 mJy estimated with the modified-blackbody model described above. We ask for an rms of 0.2 mJy/beam per 200 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line at SNR~3 in 2 to 3 consecutive 200 km/s channels for the lowest peak line flux density of 0.6 mJy (i.e. [OI]/FIR luminosity ratio of 10^-5). We could expect to detect the line at a higher SNR and well measure the line profile at a better spectral resolution of ~100 km/s if the [OI]/FIR luminosity ratio is higher as discussed above. According to the sensitivity calculator, the on-source time is ~34 minutes and the total observing time is 1.33 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.037 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect the dust continuum emission at a very high SNR.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2310_NII
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [N II] 122 micron fine structure line and dust continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We request to observe the [N II] 122 micron line emission from J2310+1855. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line at 0.6" resolution suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of ~3.2 kpc (deconvolved source size of FWHM~0.6"). Here we request to observe the [N II] line at ~0.6" resolution, i.e. in C34-2 configuration. The resolution is comparable to the observations of other fine structure and CO lines we propose here, and is sufficient to accurately determine the total flux and measure/tightly constrain the source size of the [N II] line emission. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] detection is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [N II] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: The FIR luminosity estimated with previous submillimeter and millimeter observations and a modified-blackbody model (T_dust of 47 K and emissivity index of 1.6, typical for high-z millimeter bright quasars, Beelen et al. 2006) is about 2.4x10^13 Lsun. Adopting the typical [N II]/FIR luminosity ratio range of 3x10^-5 to 1.5x10^-4 for AGN-starburst systems (Gracia-Carpio et al. 2011), we estimate the [N II] line flux to be 0.6 to 2.8 Jy km/s with peak line flux density of 1.4 to 7.1 mJy. The [C II] FWHM line width of 400 km/s is used in the calculation. The dust continuum flux density at the [N II] frequency is 15 mJy estimated with the modified-blackbody model described above. We ask for an rms of 0.3 mJy/beam per 100 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line at SNR>4 in 3 to 4 consecutive 100 km/s channels given the line flux range discussed above. According to the sensitivity calculator, the on-source time is ~38 minutes and the total observing time is 1.4 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.043 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect the dust continuum emission at a very high SNR.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2310_OIII
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [O III] 88 micron fine structure line and dust continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We request to observe the [O III] 88 micron line emission from J2310+1855. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line at 0.6" resolution suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of ~3.2 kpc (deconvolved source size of FWHM~0.6"). Here we request to observe the [O III] line at ~0.42" resolution, i.e. in C34-2 configuration. The resolution is comparable to the observations of other fine structure and CO lines we propose here, and is sufficient to accurately determine the total flux and measure/tightly constrain the source size of the [O III] line emission. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] detection is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [O III] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: The FIR luminosity estimated with previous submillimeter and millimeter observations and a modified-blackbody model (T_dust of 47 K and emissivity index of 1.6, typical for high-z millimeter bright quasars, Beelen et al. 2006) is about 2.4x10^13 Lsun. Adopting the typical [OIII]/FIR luminosity ratio range of 1x10^-4 to 3x10^-4 for AGN-starburst systems (Gracia-Carpio et al. 2011), we estimate the [O III] line flux to be 1.4 to 4.1 Jy km/s with peak line flux density of 3.4 to 10.3 mJy. The [C II] FWHM line width of 400 km/s is used in the calculation. The dust continuum flux density at the [O III] frequency is 24.5 mJy estimated with the modified-blackbody model described above. We ask for an rms of 1.1 mJy/beam per 200 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line at SNR~3 in 2 to 3 consecutive 200 km/s channels for the lowest peak line flux density of 3.4 mJy (i.e. [OIII]/FIR luminosity ratio of 10^-4). We could expect to detect the line at a higher SNR and well measure the line profile at a better spectral resolution of ~100 km/s if the [OIII]/FIR luminosity ratio is higher as discussed above. According to the sensitivity calculator, the on-source time is ~35 minutes and the total observing time is 1.33 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.26 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect the dust continuum emission at a very high SNR.

[Configuration and correlator setup]: We request to observe the CO (8-7) line emission from J2310+1855 at z=6.0031. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line at 0.6" resolution suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over scale of ~3.2 kpc (deconvolved source size of FWHM~0.6"). Here we request to observe the CO (8-7) line at ~0.6" resolution, i.e. in C34-5 configuration. The resolution is comparable to the observations of other fine structure and CO lines we propose here, and is sufficient to accurately determine the total flux and measure/tightly constrain the source size of the line. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] detection is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (8-7) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Our PdBI observation of the CO (6-5) line indicates a line flux of 1.52 +/- 0.13 Jy km/s. Based on the single-component LVG model of CO excitation in the star forming region of quasar host galaxies at high redshift (CO (8-7)/CO (6-5) flux ratio of 0.75, Riechers et al. 2009), we estimate the CO (8-7) flux to be 1.1 Jy km/s and a line peak flux density of 2.3 mJy. however, the line flux could be much higher as an additional AGN-heated molecular gas component is indicated by the detection of the CO (10-9) line (Figure 1). We adopt the CO (6-5) FWHM line width of 460 km/s in the calculation. The dust continuum flux density at the CO (8-7) frequency, estimated with previous submillimeter and millimeter observations and a modified-blackbody model (T_dust of 47 K and emissivity index of 1.6), is ~1.2 mJy. Here we ask for an rms of 0.3 mJy/beam per 75 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line at SNR>7 in 5 to 6 consecutive 75 km/s channels. According to the sensitivity calculator, the on-source time is ~37 minutes and the total observing time is 1.32 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.023 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect the dust continuum emission at a very high SNR.

[Configuration and correlator setup]: We request to observe the CO (9-8) line emission from J2310+1855 at z=6.0031. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line at 0.6" resolution suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of ~3.2 kpc (deconvolved source size of FWHM~0.6"). Here we request to observe the CO (9-8) line at ~0.5" resolution, i.e. in C34-5 configuration. The resolution is comparable to the observations of other fine structure and CO lines we propose here, and is sufficient to accurately determine the total flux and measure/tightly constrain the source size of the line. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] detection is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (9-8) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Our PdBI observation of the CO (6-5) line indicates a line flux of 1.52 +/- 0.13 Jy km/s. Based on the single-component LVG model of CO excitation in the star forming region of quasar host galaxies at high redshift (CO (9-8)/CO (6-5) flux ratio of 0.33, Riechers et al. 2009), we estimate the CO (9-8) flux to be 0.5 Jy km/s and a line peak flux density of 1.0 mJy. however, the line flux could be much higher as an additional AGN-heated molecular gas component is indicated by the detection of the CO (10-9) line (Figure 1). In particular, if we adopt the observed line flux ratio of CO (9-8)/CO (6-5)=0.6 found in J1148+5251 (Riechers et al. 2013, in prep.), the line flux is expected to be 2.5 Jy km/s with a line peak of 5.0 mJy. We adopt the CO (6-5) FWHM line width of 460 km/s in the calculation. The dust continuum flux density at the CO (9-8) frequency, estimated with previous submillimeter and millimeter observations and a modified-blackbody model (T_dust of 47 K and emissivity index of 1.6), is ~1.7 mJy. Here we ask for an rms of 0.3 mJy/beam per 75 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line at SNR~ or > 3 in 5 to 6 consecutive 75 km/s channels. According to the sensitivity calculator, the on-source time is ~28 minutes and the total observing time is 1.16 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.025 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect the dust continuum emission at a very high SNR.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observations of the [OI] 145 micron, [NII] 122 micron, [OIII] 88 micron, CO(9-8), and (8-7) line emission and a complete study of the physical conditions of the interstellar medium (ISM) in the most millimeter luminous quasar, J2310+1855 at z=6.0031. This object is the brightest dust continuum, CO (6-5), and [CII] line source in our millimeter survey of high-redshift quasars. The detections suggest intense star formation in the quasar host galaxy while the optical/NIR observations reveal a luminous AGN with broad absorption line features. Thus, this object provides a unique laboratory and an outstanding example for detailed studies of the star-forming ISM in the most massive quasar-starburst systems at the reionization era. At z~6, a full set of fine structure lines, as well as the high-J CO transitions, are well covered by the spectral windows of ALMA Cycle 2. These lines trace different phases of the ISM. The observations we request here will probe the density, temperature, radiation field and metallicity of the molecular/neutral/ionized ISM, and address how star formation and AGN activities contribute to the heating and excitation of the ISM in the nuclear region.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00800.S Imaging the molecular gas and star formation in the most distant quasar host galaxies, PI: Ran Wang
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00240.S, Dust continum and [C II] line emission from quasar host galaxies at z~6, PI: Ran Wang 2012.1.00240.S, Mapping Star Formation and Gas Dynamics in Luminous Quasar Host Galaxies at z~6, PI: Ran Wang
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
